-->


# Steps to reproduce
 - Create a folder with space in it (for example `my folder`)
 - Create a simple script inside this folder (`script.ps1`)
```powershell
Write-Output "Hello, World"
```
- run with command `pwsh -File "/Users/username/my folder/script.ps1" `

# Expected behavior

Script executes successfully:
```none
Hello, World
```
Note: script does execute correctly this way if run under PowerShell Desktop under Windows

# Actual behavior

```none
➜ /Users/username pwsh -File "/Users/username/my folder/script.ps1"
The argument 'my' is not recognized as the name of a script file. Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.

Usage: pwsh[.exe] [-Login] [[-File] <filePath> [args]]
                  [-Command { - | <script-block> [-args <arg-array>]
                                | <string> [<CommandParameters>] } ]
```

Same under Windows and PowerShell 6.2.4

```none
C:\work\src>pwsh -File "my folder\script.ps1"  
The argument 'my' is not recognized as the name of a script file. Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.  
```

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
It sounds like you installed PowerShell as .NET global tool (`dotnet tool install powershell -g`)

Sadly, a PowerShell version installed this way uses a shim executable whose argument parsing is fundamentally broken  - please see #11747

By contrast, a regularly installed PowerShell 7  version isn't affected.

comments.author: orybak
comments.body:
@mklement0 yes, that's indeed how I installed it. This issue can be closed as a duplicate then. 
Thank you

title: PowerShell does not accept paths with spaces in -File argument
